A farmer and a goat are on the left side of a river and must cross by boat.
On the right side of the river, there is a wolf and a cabbage.
The boat can carry only the farmer and a single item.
If left unattended together, the wolf would eat the goat, or the goat would eat the cabbage.
How can the farmer get the goat to the right side of the river without anything being eaten?
Alright, so I've come across this classic river crossing puzzle, and I want to figure it out step by step. Let me try to break it down and think through it carefully.

First, let me summarize the problem to make sure I understand it correctly. There's a farmer on the left side of a river, along with a goat. On the right side of the river, there's a wolf and a cabbage. The farmer needs to get all of them across the river using a boat. The boat can only carry the farmer and one other item at a time. The tricky part is that if the wolf and the goat are left alone together, the wolf will eat the goat. Similarly, if the goat and the cabbage are left alone, the goat will eat the cabbage. So, the farmer has to find a way to get everyone across without any of these unfortunate incidents happening.

Okay, so let's list out what each character is:

- Farmer: Can be on either side of the river.

- Cabbage: Can be on either side, but needs protection if left with the goat.

The boat can only carry the farmer and one other item. So, each trip, the farmer can take either the goat, the wolf, or the cabbage, but not all three. The challenge is to figure out the sequence of trips that gets everyone safely across without any pair being left alone together.
